item.title: Install on usb don't boot - Ventoy / Super Grub2 Disk - loopback.cfg
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
I do not believe so. It’s basically just GRUB on an external USB drive,
with a configuration that can detect and boot operating systems on the
computer it’s booted on. GRUB2-BLS is a GRUB variant meant to be installed
with an OS, and adds support for BootLoader Specification configuration
files. Technically Super GRUB2 Disk could in the future use a version of
GRUB with BLS support, but at the moment it does not.

Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 18.0.8.7

Install medium: Sandisk USB

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted) + LUKS

Bios: Coreboot

Look into how to change it cuz we don’t want users to blow their speakers
Not sure what sound backend is used and if they can be set globally to 50% instead of defaulting to 100%

The volume level should be set to 50 to avoid speaker blowout.

(Just so you know I did apt update && apt full-upgrade after install but maybe I’m missing sound drivers?)

item.title: Systemcheck shows FDE absent in Live Mode (18.0.8.7 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 18.0.8.7

Install medium: Sandisk USB

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted) + LUKS

Bios: Coreboot

I’ll need to double check my notes, but the Syscheck notification popup error reports “FDE absent” when booting into Live Mode. My guess is that Live Mode running as a regular USER lacks the necessary privileges to perform the check. I selected FDE and selected LUKS at install. LUKS passphrase is still needed before I get anywhere, so it works. Luks was unlocked long before and I selected FDE in the installer and my files are decrypted so LUKS is present I would think?

Additionally, the Syscheck error notification can be quite annoying when operating in Live Mode as a USER. To get it to go away you have to mask it first in non Live Mode.
I don’t mind it normally poping up for USER in normal mode but for Live Mode I could do without it tbh.

Would it even be possible to disable or mask the service for user in live mode (Not sysmaint), and would it make sense? Avoiding seeing after a new install after booting into user in live mode, while still showing it in normal session for user (they would still have the option to do systemctl --user mask updatecheck.service)

If we apply this would it also prevent the “Live Check Indicator” systray icon (the yellow circle) from appearing or is that unrelated to this?

item.title: Kicksecure Installer Settings (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
arraybolt3:

FYI, Kicksecure 18 is out and 17 will likely be deprecated soon. If you have the time, you might want to give it a shot, it has a lot of neat security improvements over version 17 (like Wayland by default and a “panic button” for instant shutdown).

Feeling kinda stupid here but I meant 18.0.8.7 NOT 17. I saw that post at the top of forum when formatting this post and thought that post for most recent. I’m on 18.0.8.7 not the pre LXQT release sorry for goofing.

arraybolt3:

Using Etc/UTC as a timezone is more of an anonymity measure than a security one, and we generally keep the anonymity enhancements in Whonix. That being said, this does still sound like a useful feature, maybe you could file a request for this at https://codeberg.org/Calamares/calamares/issues?

Well I can’t say your not right, I guess I never really looked for it when using GUI installer as I would always set it afterwards. For me personally it’s about javascript fingerprinting/browser thing for me, but again that is anonymity thang. Although on a “user choice” basis it makes sense to provide the option to set the keymap. To my knowledge I know little about it. Is more then just a configuration thing with Calamares?

arraybolt3:

That would also be a good thing to file a feature request for. Doesn’t look like the feature exists at first glance.

Was not aware if it did exist or not, but hey I’ll try to file one. Would be a cool first if Kicksecure was first to implement it. When you get a luks password wrong cause you couldn’t view it first when you initially set it up you will always remember the experience.

item.title: Well done me... idiot
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Thanks for that.

Nah, its not really a big issue. I have always stored important stuff in Proton Drive or off-device, so no great losses.

I was planning to upgrade my NVMe anyway. The device I have is only 256GB, so 512GB was on my short-term agenda.

Also, getting a bit sick of Linux Mint’s increasing ‘bloat’ and thought I’d like to go Debian for a try…

So, all good really. Plenty of drive space now and a new learning curve, plus I already have KS setup to my liking, very easy to do ultimately.

Cheers though.

(P.S. Keyboard backlight code you sent worked a treat, again.That’s a keeper.

)

item.title: Well done me... idiot
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
PhotoRec may prove useful. (Used this to recover important data after I unintentionally did a recursive delete on $HOME.) It’s in the Debian archives, install it on one of your SD card or USB installations of Kicksecure using sudo apt install testdisk. You’ll need an external drive around the same size as your SSD for PhotoRec to save recovered data to, and you’ll need to be booted from an external USB to use it.

Whatever you do, power off the system ASAP and don’t use the internal SSD for anything until you’ve recovered data from it. The longer you use it, the lower the chances of recovering important data.

Works a treat, but…

item.title: Use GUID Partition Table (GPT) by default
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Quote ticket calamares - use gpt by default:

  • Patrick: bug: unencrypted installations are mbr by default
  • Patrick: todo: port from master boot record (MBR) to GUID Partition Table (GPT), if sane
  • Aaron: Likely not a good idea until a Calamares release with Hybrid bootloader (BIOS+UEFI) installation support by ArrayBolt3 · Pull Request #2422 · calamares/calamares · GitHub in it is made (the version in Trixie doesn’t have this yet). We’d have to introduce a bios-grub partition unconditionally on both EFI and BIOS, and only one bootloader would be installed. This would mean that BIOS systems would end up with a bios_boot partition and no ESP, while EFI systems would get both bios_boot and ESP partitions but only an EFI bootloader installed. Once the linked PR is present in a release, we will be able to always have both partitions and both bootloaders.
    • Aaron: Technically GRUB can be installed on BIOS systems without a bios_boot partition, but grub-install must be run with --force to do this, and the bootloader may break at any time if this is done. See Their whole art, is this: “It is impossible to cogitate this systematic.

The blocklists are unreliable because the filesystems can move the files around at will and so the exact sectors are subject to change. Any such change creates both a reliability and security problem. Previously the blocks were only rarely moved around. However, now, with features like tail repacking and online defragmenter it will become increasingly of a problem.

item.title: ISO - Development
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description: • Install on usb don't boot - Ventoy / Super Grub2 Disk - loopback.cfg

item.title: Install on usb don't boot - Ventoy / Super Grub2 Disk - loopback.cfg
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Patrick:

This might be possible once Kicksecure ISO build process gets ported to Debian live-build.

Kicksecure ISO build process is using live-build for a while now.

A live-build fix had been submitted to and merged by upstream live-build which makes live-build compatible with dracut:

GitLab

Handle loopback booting with dracut-live properly (!376) · Merge requests ·...

dracut uses the iso-scan/filename kernel parameter for loopback booting with tools like Super Grub Disk, whereas live-boot uses the findiso parameter for this purpose. Conditionally set...

Kicksecure should now be compatible with loopback.cfg.

supergrubdisk.org

Loopback.cfg - Super Grub Disk Wiki

Kicksecure ticket: live-build - grub.cfg GRUB configuration - loopback.cfg

Quote @arraybolt3:

  • Aaron: This is now working out-of-the-box with the Kicksecure 18 ISO on BIOS systems. On EFI systems, a bug in GRUB 2.06 prevents loopback ISO boot, but there is a workaround: Loopback booting of ISOs broken because of TPM module · Issue #134 · supergrub/supergrub · GitHub

In result:

  • Kicksecure compatibility with Ventoy: Remains untested.
  • Kicksecure compatibltiy with Super Grub2 Disk: Was tested to be functional by @arraybolt3.
    • Broken by default in the Super Grub2 Disk release at the time of writing. A workaround is available. See above link.
      • The bug seems unspecific to Kicksecure and might be applicable to all Linux distributions. So there is nothing further that can be done on the Kicksecure side.
    • Might be fixed by default if Super Grub2 Disk updates its version of GRUB.

item.title: Kicksecure IPv6 Default Settings (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
exfil:

I recall reading that the security‑misc profile disables the entire IPv6 stack.

exfil:

Networking:

Optional - Disable the entire IPv6 stack to reduce attack surface.

Optional: Meaning, not by default.

exfil:

But it doesn’t point to the exact configuration file that implements this.

/etc/default/grub.d/40_kernel_hardening.cfg

#GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX="$GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX ipv6.disable=1"

The ipv6.disable=1 is commented out (disabled) by default, it has no effect. See also Commenting Syntax and Effects.

Since we don’t enable ipv6.disable=1, IPv6 remains enabled by default.

Btw: Search the Source Code

exfil:

1. Does Disabling IPv6 reduce Tor Anonymity set?

Unspecific to Kicksecure:

Kicksecure – 6 Sep 24

Potential Solutions Beyond Kicksecure!

Explore resources outside of Kicksecure to address unspecific questions or issues.

Suitable for:

Kicksecure – 18 May 25

Self Support First Policy for Kicksecure

Definition of the Self Support First Policy for Kicksecure

item.title: Kicksecure 17 End of Security Support and Deprecation Notice - All users should move to Kicksecure 18!
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
As per Kicksecure Support Schedule, this post serves as the Kicksecure version 17 deprecation notice.

Kicksecure 18 stable has been released for all platforms.

  • Kicksecure 18 Released! Major Release Upgrade!
  • Kicksecure 18 for Qubes Released! Major Release Upgrade!

Kicksecure 17 will be deprecated on 06 February 2026.

All users should upgrade!

The more time that passes after the deprecation date, the harder or even impossible it might become to perform an in-place release upgrade.

Platform specific notice:

  • Non-Qubes-Kicksecure: No special notice.
  • Qubes-Kicksecure: Quote Support Schedule
  • Version 17: The goal is to provide support for as long as Qubes R4.2 receives security support from Qubes and Debian. [footnote in wiki]

Version: Kicksecure 17.4.4.6

There is really no need to get started with version 17 at this point. Highly discouraged. Reports against 17 will be mostly moot. Unless it’s a high severity security bug or release upgrade issue, nothing will happen to version 17.

See also: Kicksecure 18 Released! Major Release Upgrade!

lxqt

Kicksecure 17 came with Xfce by default.
Kicksecure 18 comes with LXQt by default.
Hence, I am wondering if you’re actually using version 17 or 18?

If the version number is wrong, please edit in your recent reports.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
desi_fubu:

Are you trying to start the cloned system on SD card in Live Mode?

The insufficient memory error doesn’t sound like storage but RAM?

I have had success with booting Tails from SD card by editing and removing live-media=removable boot option flag at the Grub startup screen. I don’t see a dracut.cmdline option that is similar which is what Kicksecure uses, so that flag doesn’t apply.

Ummm, I had no problems in the end with either mode, live iso or persistent. As a matter of fact, once booted from the MicroSD, you can ‘shutdown’ or ‘reboot’ the computer whenever you want and it will default to booting from the SD slot/card until the card is removed. Then, its going through the grub boot menu again first-up.

Also, I have never had to adjust the TAILS OS default settings to boot from either the USB stick or the MicroSD card, though it is always via the grub boot menu.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @Avoca

Ok, so, using Linux dd as a cloning tool, I have installed KS/Whonix on a MicroSD card.

It won’t ‘boot’ directly from the SD Card slot on my laptop but it does show-up/boot from the grub Boot Menu without issue.

I suspect it will auto-boot from an appropriate SD → USB adaptor inserted in a USB port, as does the USB version of the install.

I just don’t have one at hand…

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
desi_fubu:

@arraybolt3 is there any know issues with dracut and sd cards when it comes to booting them from BIOS?

None that I know of (though I haven’t looked very closely, so don’t take my statement as reliable).

I just checked Bugs in package dracut -- Debian Bug report logs and Bugs in package dracut-core -- Debian Bug report logs and don’t see any mention of sd or mmc there, so it looks like there aren’t Debian bug reports about SD card issues with Dracut either.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @desi_fubu
item.description:
Wanted to chime in here on my experience. It depends on the BIOS, its usually later versions of UEFI BIOS that support this. Never have found a Legacy BIOS that supports booting from SD card, but this doesn’t sound to be your case.

[quote=“Avoca, post:5, topic:1463”]
I then tried from the 64GB USB to a 32GB MicroSD and it failed with ~“insufficient memory” as the error message.
[/quote]

Are you trying to start the cloned system on SD card in Live Mode?

The insufficient memory error doesn’t sound like storage but RAM?

I have had success with booting Tails from SD card by editing and removing live-media=removable boot option flag at the Grub startup screen. I don’t see a dracut.cmdline option that is similar which is what Kicksecure uses, so that flag doesn’t apply.

Was gonna say if it was failure to boot maybe the mmc_block or sdhci aren’t loaded correctly. In this case might want to look at rd.driver.pre=mmc_block,sdhci but I haven’t even tried booting a dracut system off a SD card. Now you got me wanting to see if the Live ISO will boot on my laptop that supports SD card boots in UEFI.

@arraybolt3 is there any know issues with dracut and sd cards when it comes to booting them from BIOS?

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
If I can get work time allocated to this, I’ll work on it. As a short-term solution, you can run something like this while booted into PERSISTENT Mode | SYSMAINT Session | system maintenance tasks:

cat <<EOF | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/set-apple-kb-backlight.service
[Unit]
Description=Enable keyboard backlight on Apple systems

[Service]
Type=oneshot
RemainAfterExit=yes
ExecStart=bash -c -- 'echo 255 > /sys/class/leds/smc::kbd_backlight/brightness'

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target sysmaint-boot.target
EOF
sudo systemctl daemon-reload
sudo systemctl enable set-apple-kb-backlight.service
sudo systemctl start set-apple-kb-backlight.service

This should make the backlight immediately turn on, and it should be automatically turned on each time you boot up thereafter. If max brightness is too intense, change the 255 in echo 255 to a smaller value. (This will create a new file at /etc/systemd/system/set-apple-kb-backlight.service, so if you need to change things later, that’s the file to change.)

(The ideal solution would be for Kicksecure’s backlight-tool to display the keyboard backlight as an additional device with controllable brightness, but that will take a lot longer to make happen.)

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
VirtualBox just not working with Secure Boot enabled is a big problem, so I’ll put this on my todo list and hopefully find a solution soon.

Edit: This turns out to be a VirtualBox limitation; VBox upstream doesn’t use DKMS, whereas the VirtualBox Debian packages that were available to us in Bookworm did. Debian also doesn’t have the tool VirtualBox tries to use to automatically sign its kernel modules. Thus fixing this will require either Debian or VirtualBox to do something different. Filed a feature request:

github.com/VirtualBox/virtualbox

[Req]: Use DKMS for signing the vboxdrv and other modules rather than (or in addition to) `update-secureboot-policy`

opened 03:40AM - 05 Jan 26 UTC
ArrayBolt3
enhancement

### Component Host Installer ### What problem are you facing? At the moment, …VirtualBox uses the `update-secureboot-policy` tool to create and enroll MOK keys. This tool supposedly exists on both Ubuntu and Debian, however the `update-secureboot-policy` tool on Debian is a radically different tool with a different purpose than the `update-secureboot-policy` tool on Ubuntu. Under Ubuntu, the tool's purpose is enrolling MOK keys, while under Debian, the tool's purpose is turning Secure Boot validation on or off entirely. That means that the VirtualBox package only works out of the box on Ubuntu at the moment if Secure Boot is enabled, despite `/usr/sbin/rcvboxdrv` claiming it works on Debian 10 and later. ### How can we fix this? Consider using DKMS to build the VirtualBox kernel modules instead of manually building them under Debian. This will allow integrating with the existing module signing infrastructure already in Debian, and would likely also work on Ubuntu as well. Unless there are other distributions that have `update-secureboot-policy`, this would remove the need for `update-secureboot-policy`. ### What alternatives or workarounds exist? Manually signing the module works, which is what the user is told to do if automatic signing fails. This requires manual intervention with every VirtualBox upgrade. ### Anything else we should know? Request is inspired by a Kicksecure bug report: https://forums.kicksecure.com/t/virtualbox-error-kernel-driver-not-installed-rc-1908/1453

Edit 2: I’ve found a workaround! In the sysmaint session, run:

sudo mkdir -p /var/lib/shim-signed/mok
sudo ln -s /var/lib/dkms/mok.key /var/lib/shim-signed/mok/MOK.priv
sudo ln -s /var/lib/dkms/mok.pub /var/lib/shim-signed/mok/MOK.der
sudo apt reinstall virtualbox-7.2

This makes it so that VirtualBox can find the signing keys the wiki directs you to enroll. It then signs its kernel modules with them, and things work. I was able to successfully get VirtualBox working on Kicksecure 18 with Secure Boot enabled by doing this.

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Avoca:

However, TAILS OS seems to have solved it as, once loaded, the standard keyboard backlight adjustments work. Never needed to try/look into the actual ‘settings’ system, so I don’t know.

Tails doesn’t have user-sysmaint-split or a similar “isolate root access into a non-standard user account”, so it doesn’t have the same issues there. GNOME also has built-in support for adjusting the backlight.

Avoca:

Happy to offer my help/computer for testing a fix if it helps. Proton Mail, Tuta Mail, PGP, Session, Delta Chat, etc, available if it helps.

What would probably be most helpful is if you could share the output of cd /sys/class/leds/smc::kbd_backlight && grep . *. This will show the names and contents of all the files in that directory. That might provide enough information to write a utility that will work with Kicksecure and will allow adjusting the backlight, and depending on how things go, that might be something that can be integrated into Kicksecure later (though @Patrick would be the one to decide that).

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Correct!

Initially I cloned from 32GB USB to 64GB USB drive’s and it worked, no issues.

I then tried from the 64GB USB to a 32GB MicroSD and it failed with ~“insufficient memory” as the error message.

So, off the the store for me.

Still very hopeful though.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: Is the SD card bigger than the USB drive? If so, it should just work. (Growing the root partition could be challenging, I’m not sure we have that documented anywhere, but even without growing the partition, the system should work.) Of course, if the card is smaller, then there are problems. Generally it’s a good idea to clone from a smaller drive to a bigger drive rather than cloning between two drives of the same size, since two drives that claim to be the same size (32 GB for instance) might be slightly different sizes “under the hood”, which can give you the same complications as cloning to a too-small drive.

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Thanks, I figured Apple would be behind yet another UEFI/BIOS hurdle.

However, TAILS OS seems to have solved it as, once loaded, the standard keyboard backlight adjustments work. Never needed to try/look into the actual ‘settings’ system, so I don’t know.

Happy to offer my help/computer for testing a fix if it helps. Proton Mail, Tuta Mail, PGP, Session, Delta Chat, etc, available if it helps.

Cheers.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?

Thanks.

So far so good. I am using Linux dd to ‘clone’ the USB to a MicroSD card and, apart from a device size mismatch(my bad), its looking good.

I can boot my MicroSD TAILS OS from the grub boot menu whilst its in the SD slot or when mounted in a USB-A/C adaptor, but they are different from the Kicksecure boot method, so it remains to be seen if it works.

But, I’ll report back when I have purchased a matching size MicroSD.

I’m very hopeful.

item.title: Virtualbox error Kernel driver not installed (rc=-1908)
item.dc:creator: @ValdemarJo
item.description: It looks like the problem is the latest update, I reinstalled the system again and did everything new, but nothing helped. I would be grateful if someone tries to run any operating system in VirtualBox in the latest version of KickSecure with secureboot enabled.

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: We don’t usually change the polkit policies unless necessary for security reasons. One exception is Flatpak; we changed its polkit policies to prohibit things like unprivileged system-wide software installation.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description: I have not personally tried this (systems that are able to boot from an SD card slot are rather rare in my experience), but I see no reason why it shouldn’t work. As long as your system’s firmware can access the SD card at boot time, you should be able to just install Kicksecure onto it like you’d install it persistently on a USB drive, and then use it. Linux sees SD cards as block device just like USB drives and internal drives, so there should be no issues there.

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
This might be a tricky one. Apple keyboard backlights are apparently controlled by a sysfs file, which likely requires administrator permissions to modify. Existing tools might not work with user-sysmaint-split installed unless they install a privileged background process that actually does the job of changing the backlight brightness. If you remove user-sysmaint-split though, you might be able to use something like brightnessctl to adjust the keyboard backlight.

I unfortunately do not have an Intel-based Macbook to test with, so I can’t really create a tool for adjusting this that integrates with Kicksecure. (I made a tool for adjusting the display backlight, which is part of Kicksecure 18; a similar tool would probably work for the keyboard backlight, but would require someone with compatible hardware to create the tool or add support for keyboard backlight changing to the existing tool.)

item.title: Kicksecure IPv6 Default Settings (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
exfil:

Does disabling the IPv6 network stack on my machine then in return prevent the Tor Daemons from using IPv6 relays? (Reduced relay pool to select from)
Will Tor only connect to IPv4 relays and ignore IPv6 relays?

For guard relays, almost certainly yes. If your machine can’t connect to other machines over IPv6, Tor won’t be able to either. The guard relays however might then talk to other relays that do have IPv6 support.

exfil:

Can we enable full IPv6 (for Tor daemon’s IPv6 relay access and machine outbound) with privacy extensions, while maintaining a stable IPv6 address bound to your DHCPv6 server’s DUID for reliable client leasing and server reachability as to not add breakage for users needing the IPv6 server?

Not sure, research in this area would be welcome if a contributor is interested in working on it. My experience with IPv6 automatic address assignment is mostly with SLAAC, so I don’t have much insight into what can be done with DHCPv6.

item.title: Kicksecure Installer Settings (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
exfil:

Version: Kicksecure 17.4.4.6

FYI, Kicksecure 18 is out and 17 will likely be deprecated soon. If you have the time, you might want to give it a shot, it has a lot of neat security improvements over version 17 (like Wayland by default and a “panic button” for instant shutdown).

exfil:

Under timezone there is no Etc/UTC which I really wanted to set and had to set after post install timedatectl set-timezone "Etc/UTC". This isn’t really Kicksecures fault but a Calamares configuration issue. I believe this timezone is omitted or ignored in the default installer but I haven’t digged enough yet to see.

Using Etc/UTC as a timezone is more of an anonymity measure than a security one, and we generally keep the anonymity enhancements in Whonix. That being said, this does still sound like a useful feature, maybe you could file a request for this at https://codeberg.org/Calamares/calamares/issues?

exfil:

Is there a way to expose a “show password” option for the LUKS field in the Calamares configuration? If not, perhaps this could be proposed upstream to libkpmcore?

That would also be a good thing to file a feature request for. Doesn’t look like the feature exists at first glance.

item.title: KS/Whonix on MicroSD?
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Hi all,

Ok, so I’m a TAILS OS user from wayback, but, as you all know, its not the most convenient ‘daily driver’ option, hence, I like the idea of KS/Whonix on a persistent USB.

To that end, has anyone manged to clone this configuration to a MicroSD card?

I have my ‘persistent’ TAILS OS on a 32GB MicroSD, which makes portable concealment that much easier.

Cheers.

item.title: MacBook Pro keyboard backlight issue
item.dc:creator: @Avoca
item.description:
Hi all,

I can’t for the life of me workout how to adjust the keyboard backlight on my Intel MacBook Pro.

The “Keyboard & Mouse” settings panel in KS is not an option because it is non-functional and the suggested workaround is beyond my pay grade at this early stage.

The actual keyboard ‘keys’ do nothing.

Tips and advice greatly appreciated.

Cheers.

item.title: Can't open proton VPN in kicksecure 18
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description: Does Kicksecure set Polkit policies for default shipped apps or common apps for user stability?

item.title: KS persistent USB install issue, Linux Mint/Intel MacBook Pro
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
arraybolt3:

Edit: You “created two equal Live ISO images, each on a separate USB Drive, as per instructions”? I don’t think the instructions say to do that; you aren’t supposed to flash the Kicksecure ISO to the installation target drive. You’re only supposed to flash it to the installation source drive, then you boot from the source drive and install Kicksecure to the target drive like you’d install it to an internal drive. wipefs will probably fix the target drive in this scenario.

Yeah you install the ISO to USB like you would any Linux ISO, then at GRUB screen select SYSMAINT installation. Then once booted to the desktop where the SYSMAINT panel appears plug in another flash drive and start the Installer then the other USB drive will appear as a media selection to install Kicksecure onto. This is no different then installing on internal or external HDD/SSD, you just got to make sure you plug in the media you wish to install from so the installer can read it and make sure you select the right drive.

item.title: Kicksecure IPv6 Default Settings (17.4.4.6 Feedback)
item.dc:creator: @exfil
item.description:
Installation Details

Version: Kicksecure 17.4.4.6

Install medium: Sandisk USB

Partition format: ext4 (auto-formatted)

I recall reading that the security‑misc profile disables the entire IPv6 stack. After installing, however, I verified that IPv6 is still active:
Upon post install I checked and cat /proc/sys/net/ipv6/conf/all/disable_ipv6 returned 0 (enabled) and ip -6 addr show returned a inet6 address.

I had to create a config file /etc/sysctl.d/99_disable-ipv6.conf with these lines to disable it:

net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6=1
net.ipv6.conf.default.disable_ipv6=1

Upon further looking at the github README:

Networking:

Optional - Disable the entire IPv6 stack to reduce attack surface.

But it doesn’t point to the exact configuration file that implements this.

I’m not using this installation as a server, and I’m skeptical of the “IPv6 evangelism” that circulates in many networking sysadmin circles, not Kicksecure. My concerns stem mainly from two points:

  • IPv6 doesn’t provide the implicit NAT barrier that IPv4 does.
  • Privacy implications of EUI‑64 that can expose hardware identifiers.

So here are two questions about IPv6 and Kicksecure.

1. Does Disabling IPv6 reduce Tor Anonymity set?

Does disabling the IPv6 network stack on my machine then in return prevent the Tor Daemons from using IPv6 relays? (Reduced relay pool to select from)
Will Tor only connect to IPv4 relays and ignore IPv6 relays?

2. Can we have IPv6 privacy extensions enabled without breaking root DHCP server?

Can we enable full IPv6 (for Tor daemon’s IPv6 relay access and machine outbound) with privacy extensions, while maintaining a stable IPv6 address bound to your DHCPv6 server’s DUID for reliable client leasing and server reachability as to not add breakage for users needing the IPv6 server?

Config note here worth mentioning man nm-settings-dbus

The special values “llt” and “ll” will generate a DUID of type LLT or LL (see RFC 3315) based on the current MAC address of the device.
dhcp-duid=ll # Fallbacks to link-local DUID for IPv6

The bottom line is can we keep a stable, DUID derived address for server accessibility while also generating temporary privacy focused addresses for outbound traffic (Tor relay/daemon and general machine use like e.g. in a users post about reticulum use)?
